page.title: 18Frenchay Hospital
page.content: {Frenchay Hospital}was opened in 1931 for the care of tuberculous children. It consisted of a large mansion in 70 acres of land and housed 100 beds and a school for 30 children. During the 2nd World War it was staffed by American troops and many single-storey buildings were erected. These are still in use. In 1948 the NHS reorganised Britain's hospitals and Frenchay began its specialised areas of surgery:Thoracic, Neuro and Plastic. Since then the hospital has expanded to become a large general hospital including a major accident unit. It still has a school for its young patients. The Hospital has 546 beds and employs 2000 staff to care for 15000 In-patients, 70000 Out-patients and 10000 Day patients annually.
